This means that
$\vec{c}$ cannot possibly be in the range of \emph{C} and so there will

hints_html: To check if a linear system has a solution, we can look at the relationships between two of the fundamental subspaces of a matrix. Which ones should we look at? How are they related?
hints_latex:
To check if a linear system has a solution, we can look at the
relationships between two of the fundamental subspaces of a matrix.
Which ones should we look at? How are they related?
hints_raw: To check if a linear system has a solution, we can look at the relationships between two of the fundamental subspaces of a matrix.  Which ones should we look at?  How are they related?
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Since \(\vec{a}=s_1\vec{a_1}+s_2\vec{a_2}=s_1\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -3\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}+s_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\)\(=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ -3& 0\\ 0& 0\\ 0& 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} s_1\\ s_2 \end{bmatrix}\)

Using the equation from part (c), we have

\(B\vec{a}=\vec{b}\)

\(\begin{bmatrix} 8 & 4 & 2 &1 \\ 1 &1 &1 &1 \\ 0& 0 & 0&1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ -3& 0\\ 0& 0\\ 0& 1 \end{bmatrix}\vec{s}=\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\)

Therefore,

\(C=\begin{bmatrix} -4 &1 \\ -2& 1\\ 0& 1 \end{bmatrix}\) and \(\vec{c}=\vec{b}=\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\).

Notice that for there to be a solution we need \(\vec{c}\) in the range of C, R(C). We know that R(C) is the orthogonal complement to the nullspace of \(C^T\), \(N(C^T)\). Therefore, onsider the basis vector of \(N(C^T)\) \(\begin{bmatrix} -4 & -2 & 0\\ 1& 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\vec{x}=0\rightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 2 &1 &0 \\ 0& 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\vec{x}=0\)

\(\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2\\ x_3 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}x_3\)

Since \(\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}=2-4+1\neq 0\)

In other words, \(N(C^T)\) is not orthogonal to \(\vec{c}\). This means that \(\vec{c}\) cannot possibly be in the range of C and so there will be no solution to the problem.
sols_latex:
Since $\vec{a}=s_1\vec{a_1}+s_2\vec{a_2}=s_1\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-3\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix}+s_2\begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
0\\ 
0\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}$$=\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0\\ 
-3& 0\\ 
0& 0\\ 
0& 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
s_1\\ 
s_2
\end{bmatrix}$

Using the equation from
{part
(c)}, we have

$B\vec{a}=\vec{b}$

$\begin{bmatrix}
8 & 4 & 2 &1 \\ 
1 &1 &1 &1 \\ 
0& 0 & 0&1 
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0\\ 
-3& 0\\ 
0& 0\\ 
0& 1
\end{bmatrix}\vec{s}=\begin{bmatrix}
2\\ 
2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}$

Therefore,

$C=\begin{bmatrix}
-4 &1 \\ 
-2& 1\\ 
0& 1
\end{bmatrix}$ and $\vec{c}=\vec{b}=\begin{bmatrix}
2\\ 
2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}$.

Notice that for there to be a solution we need $\vec{c}$ in the range of
\emph{C}, \emph{R(C)}. We know that \emph{R(C)} is the orthogonal
complement to the nullspace of $C^T$, $N(C^T)$. Therefore, onsider the
basis vector of $N(C^T)$ $\begin{bmatrix}
-4 & -2 & 0\\ 
1& 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\vec{x}=0\rightarrow \begin{bmatrix}
2 &1 &0 \\ 
0& 1 & 2
\end{bmatrix}\vec{x}=0$

$\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}
x_1\\ 
x_2\\ 
x_3
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}x_3$

Since $\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix}
2\\ 
2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}=2-4+1\neq 0$

In other words, $N(C^T)$ is not orthogonal to $\vec{c}$. This means that
$\vec{c}$ cannot possibly be in the range of \emph{C} and so there will
be no solution to the problem.

<math>\begin{bmatrix}

0& 0 & 0&1

1

Therefore,

<math>C=\begin{bmatrix}

-2& 1\\ 
0& 1
\end{bmatrix}</math> and <math>\vec{c}=\vec{b}=\begin{bmatrix}
2\\ 
2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}</math>.

Notice that for there to be a solution we need <math>\vec{c}</math> in the range of ''C'', ''R(C)''. We know that ''R(C)'' is the orthogonal complement to the nullspace of <math>C^T</math>, <math>N(C^T)</math>.  Therefore, onsider the basis vector of <math>N(C^T)</math> <math>\begin{bmatrix}
-4 & -2 & 0\\ 
1& 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\vec{x}=0\rightarrow \begin{bmatrix}

0& 1 & 2
\end{bmatrix}\vec{x}=0</math>

1

Since <math>\begin{bmatrix}

1

1
\end{bmatrix}=2-4+1\neq 0</math>

In other words, <math>N(C^T)</math> is not orthogonal to <math>\vec{c}</math>.  This means that <math>\vec{c}</math> cannot possibly be in the range of ''C'' and so there will be no solution to the problem.
statement_html:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4\end{aligned}\]

(d) Using the equation in (c) find the equation Cs=c satisfied by \(\mathbf{s} = [s_1,s_2]^T\) if p(x)

(i) has coefficient vector \(\mathbf{a} = s_1\mathbf{a}_1 + s_2\mathbf{a}_2\) (and therefore has zero slope at x = 0 and x = 2).

(ii) passes through the points (0,1), (1,2) and (2,2).

Does this equation have a solution? Give a reason.
statement_latex:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4
\end{align*}

\textbf{(d)} Using the equation in
{(c)}
find the equation \emph{C\textbf{s}=\textbf{c}} satisfied by
$\mathbf{s} = [s_1,s_2]^T$ if \emph{p(x)}

(i) has coefficient vector
$\mathbf{a} = s_1\mathbf{a}_1 + s_2\mathbf{a}_2$ (and therefore has zero
slope at \emph{x = 0} and \emph{x = 2}).

(ii) passes through the points \emph{(0,1)}, \emph{(1,2)} and
\emph{(2,2)}.

Does this equation have a solution? Give a reason.
statement_raw:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

:<math> \displaystyle
p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4
</math>

'''(d)''' Using the equation in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2012/Question_01_(c)|(c)]] find the equation ''C'''s'''='''c''''' satisfied by <math>\mathbf{s} = [s_1,s_2]^T</math> if ''p(x)''

(i) has coefficient vector <math>\mathbf{a} = s_1\mathbf{a}_1 + s_2\mathbf{a}_2</math> (and therefore has zero slope at ''x = 0'' and ''x = 2'').

(ii) passes through the points ''(0,1)'', ''(1,2)'' and ''(2,2)''.

Does this equation have a solution? Give a reason.
